t: Job 20
Zophar Says, “The Triumph of the Wicked Is Short”
Then*p Zophar the Naamathite answered,
“Therefore*pn my disquieting thoughts make me respond, Even*ln because of my inward agitation.
I*ln listened to the reproof which insults me, And*ln the spirit of my understanding makes me answer.
Do*ln you know this from of old, From*ln the establishment of man on earth,
That*ln the triumphing of the wicked is short, And*ln the joy of the godless momentary?
Though*ln his loftiness reaches the heavens, And*ln his head touches the clouds,
He*ln perishes forever like his refuse; Those*ln who have seen him will say, ‘Where is he?’
He*ln flies away like a dream, and they cannot find him; Even*ln like a vision of the night he is chased away.
The*ln eye which saw him sees him no longer, And*ln his place no longer beholds him.
His*ln sons favor the poor, And*ln his hands give back his wealth.
His*ln bones are full of his youthful vigor, But*ln it lies down with him in the dust.
“Though*ln evil is sweet in his mouth And*iln he hides it under his tongue,
Though*iln he desires it and will not let it go, But*ln holds it in his mouth,
Yet*iln his food in his stomach is changed To*ln the venom of cobras within him.
He*ln swallows riches, But*ln will vomit them up; God*ln will expel them from his belly.
He*ln sucks the poison of cobras; The*ln viper’s tongue slays him.
He*ln does not look at the streams, The*ln rivers flowing with honey and curds.
He*ln returns what he has attained And*ln cannot swallow it;*i As*ln to the riches of his trading, He*ln cannot even enjoy them.*i
For*ln he has oppressed and*i forsaken the poor; He*ln has seized a house which he has not built.
“Because*ln he knew no quiet within him, He*ln does not retain anything he desires.
Nothing*ln remains for him to devour, Therefore*ln his prosperity does not endure.
In*ln the fullness of his plenty he will be cramped; The*ln hand of everyone who suffers will come against*i him.
When*ln he fills his belly, God*iln will send His fierce anger on him And*ln will rain it*i on him while he is eating.
He*ln may flee from the iron weapon, But*iln the bronze bow will pierce him.
It*ln is drawn forth and comes out of his back, Even*ln the glittering point from his gall. Terrors*ln come upon him,
Complete*ln darkness is held in reserve for his treasures, And*ln unfanned fire will devour him; It*ln will consume the survivor in his tent.
The*ln heavens will reveal his iniquity, And*ln the earth will rise up against him.
The*ln increase of his house will depart; His*iln possessions*i will flow away in the day of His anger.
This*ln is the wicked man’s portion from God, Even*ln the heritage decreed to him by God.”
